column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA3.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.29, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS sectors can contribute to achieving the target of restoring at least 20% of land areas in need of restoration by 2030. This is because reducing emissions can help mitigate climate change, which is a key driver of land degradation and restoration needs.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste in processing and manufacturing by 10% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020
column5: The implementation of TA3.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.35, as reducing food waste can help achieve the target of improving the condition of habitats and ecosystems, including those related to food production and consumption. Reducing food waste can also help reduce the environmental impacts of food production, such as greenhouse gas emissions and water pollution.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste per capita, jointly in retail and other distribution of food, in restaurants and food services and in households, by 30% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020
column5: The implementation of TA3.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.35, as reducing food waste per capita can help achieve the target of improving the condition of habitats and ecosystems, including those related to food production and consumption. Reducing food waste per capita can also help reduce the environmental impacts of food production, such as greenhouse gas emissions and water pollution.

column2: All packaging shall be recyclable
column5: The implementation of TA3.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as making all packaging recyclable can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recyclable packaging can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: The plastic part in packaging shall contain the following minimum percentage of recycled content
column5: The implementation of TA3.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as increasing the use of recycled content in packaging can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Using recycled content can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Each Member State shall reduce the packaging waste generated per capita, as compared to the packaging waste generated per capita in 2018
column5: The implementation of TA3.30 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as reducing packaging waste per capita can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Reducing packaging waste per capita can also help reduce the environmental impacts of packaging production, such as greenhouse gas emissions and water pollution.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain the recycling targets of 65% by weight of all packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 50% of plastic by weight of plastic contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.32 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for plastic can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling plastic packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 25% of wood by weight of wood contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for wood can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling wood packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 70% of ferrous metals by weight of ferrous metals contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for ferrous metals can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling ferrous metals packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 50% of aluminium by weight of aluminium contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.35 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for aluminium can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling aluminium packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 70% of glass by weight of glass contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.36 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for glass can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling glass packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall take the necessary measures to attain a recycling target of 75% of paper and cardboard by weight of paper and cardboard contained in packaging waste generated by 31 December 2025
column5: The implementation of TA3.37 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.42, as achieving the recycling target for paper and cardboard can help achieve the target of re-establishing habitats and ecosystems, including those related to packaging waste. Recycling paper and cardboard packaging waste can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Each vehicle belonging to a vehicle type that is type-approved as of [the first day of the month following 72 months after the date of entry into force of this Regulation] under Regulation (EU) 2018/858 shall be constructed so that it is: (a) reusable/recyclable to a minimum of 85% by mass
column3: (b) reusable/recoverable to a minimum of 95 % by mass
column6: The implementation of TA3.38 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.41, as increasing the recyclability and recoverability of vehicles can help achieve the target of restoring marine ecosystems, including those related to vehicle waste. Increasing the recyclability and recoverability of vehicles can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: The plastic contained in each vehicle type that is type-approved as of [the first day of the month following 72 months after the date of entry into force of the Regulation] under Regulation (EU) 2018/858 shall contain a minimum of 25 % of plastic recycled by weight from post-consumer plastic waste
column5: The implementation of TA3.48 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.41, as increasing the use of recycled plastic in vehicles can help achieve the target of restoring marine ecosystems, including those related to plastic waste. Increasing the use of recycled plastic can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: At least 25% of the target set out in the first subparagraph shall be achieved by including plastics recycled from end-of-life vehicles in the vehicle type concerned
column5: The implementation of TA3.49 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.41, as increasing the use of recycled plastic from end-of-life vehicles can help achieve the target of restoring marine ecosystems, including those related to plastic waste. Increasing the use of recycled plastic can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the following targets are met by the waste management operators: (a) the reuse and recovery, as calculated together, shall be a minimum of 95 %, by average weight per vehicle, excluding batteries, and year
column3: (b) the reuse and recycling, as calculated together, shall be a minimum of 85 %, by average weight per vehicle, excluding batteries, and year
column6: The implementation of TA3.50 is likely to have a positive impact on TA6.41, as increasing the reuse and recovery of vehicles can help achieve the target of restoring marine ecosystems, including those related to vehicle waste. Increasing the reuse and recovery of vehicles can reduce the amount of waste sent to landfills and help conserve natural resources.

column2: Terrestrial ecosystems. Member States shall put in place [...] measures [...] to jointly cover, as a Union target, throughout the areas and ecosystems [...] defined in Art. 2, by 2030, at least 20% of land areas in need of restoration and, by 2050, all ecosystems in need of restoration
column5: The implementation of TA6.29 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.23, as restoring terrestrial ecosystems can lead to increased carbon sequestration, which may reduce the need for greenhouse gas emissions reductions from the EU ETS sectors. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of reducing emissions from the EU ETS sectors.

column2: Marine ecosystems. Member States shall put in place [...] measures [...] to jointly cover, as a Union target, throughout the areas and ecosystems [...] defined in Art. 2, by 2030, at least 20% of sea areas in need of restoration and, by 2050, all ecosystems in need of restoration
column5: The implementation of TA6.30 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.23, as restoring marine ecosystems can lead to increased carbon sequestration, which may reduce the need for greenhouse gas emissions reductions from the EU ETS sectors. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of reducing emissions from the EU ETS sectors.

column2: Terrestrial, coastal and freshwater ecosystems. Member States shall put in place the restoration measures [...] to improve to good condition areas of habitat types listed in Annex I which are not in good condition
column5: The implementation of TA6.31 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.24, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for food waste reductions. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of reducing food waste.

column2: Terrestrial, coastal and freshwater ecosystems. Member States shall put in place the restoration measures [...] to re-establish the habitat types listed in Annex I in areas not covered by those habitat types with the aim to reach their favourable reference area
column5: The implementation of TA6.32 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.25, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for food waste reductions per capita. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of reducing food waste per capita.

column2: Terrestrial, coastal and freshwater ecosystems. Member States shall put in place the restoration measures for the terrestrial, coastal and freshwater habitats of the species listed in Annexes II, IV and V to Directive 92/43/EEC and of the terrestrial, coastal and freshwater habitats of wild birds covered by Directive 2009/147/EC
column5: The implementation of TA6.33 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.27, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recyclable packaging. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of making all packaging recyclable.

column2: Member States shall ensure that condition is known for at least 90% of the area distributed overall habitat types listed in Annex I by 2030 and 100% by 2040
column5: The implementation of TA6.34 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.28, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycled content in packaging. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of increasing the use of recycled content in packaging.

column2: Member States shall ensure that there is: (a) an increase of habitat area in good condition for habitat types listed in Annex I until at least 90% is in good condition and until the favourable reference area for each habitat type in each biogeographic region of the Member State concerned is reached
column5: The implementation of TA6.35 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.30, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for reducing packaging waste per capita. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of reducing packaging waste per capita.

column2: (urban ecosystems) By 2030, Member States shall ensure that there is no net loss in the total national area of urban green space, and of urban tree canopy cover in urban ecosystem areas
column5: The implementation of TA6.36 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.31, as restoring urban ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets.

column2: (urban ecosystems) Member States shall achieve thereafter an increasing trend in the total national area of urban green space, including through the integration of urban green space into buildings and infrastructure, in urban ecosystem areas, determined in accordance with Article 14(4), measured every six years after 31 December 2030, until a satisfactory level identified in accordance with Article 14(5) is reached
column5: The implementation of TA6.37 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.32, as restoring urban ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for plastic. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for plastic.

column2: (urban ecosystems) Member States shall achieve, in each urban ecosystem area, determined in accordance with Article 14(4), an increasing trend of urban tree canopy cover, measured every six years after 31 December 2030, until the satisfactory level identified in accordance with Article 14(5) is reached
column5: The implementation of TA6.38 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.33, as restoring urban ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for wood. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for wood.

column2: Natural connectivity of rivers and natural functions of the related floodplains. Member States shall make an inventory of artificial barriers and remove them to connectivity of surface waters and, taking into account their socio-economic functions, identify the barriers that need to be removed to contribute to the achievement of the restoration targets set out in Article 4 of this Regulation and of the objective of restoring at least 25.000 km of rivers into free-flowing rivers in the Union
column5: The implementation of TA6.39 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.34, as restoring natural connectivity can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for ferrous metals. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for ferrous metals.

column2: (pollinator) Member States shall, by putting in place in a timely manner appropriate and effective measures, improve pollinator diversity and reverse the decline of pollinator populations at the latest by 2030 and thereafter achieve an increasing trend of pollinator populations, measured at least every six years from 2030, until satisfactory levels are achieved, as set in accordance with Article 14(5)
column5: The implementation of TA6.40 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.35, as improving pollinator diversity can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for aluminium. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for aluminium.

column2: Marine ecosystems. Member States shall put in place the restoration measures [...] to improve [...] areas of habitat types listed in Annex II which are not in good condition
column5: The implementation of TA6.41 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.36, as restoring marine ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for glass. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for glass.

column2: Member States shall put in place the restoration measures that are necessary to re-establish the habitat types of groups 1-6 listed in Annex II in areas not covered by those habitat types with the aim to reach their favourable reference area
column5: The implementation of TA6.42 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.37, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycling targets for paper and cardboard. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving recycling targets for paper and cardboard.

column2: Member States shall ensure, by 2030 at the latest, that the condition is known for at least 50% of the area distributed over all habitat types listed in groups 1–6 of Annex II. The condition of all areas of groups 1–6 of habitat types listed in Annex II shall be known by 2040
column5: The implementation of TA6.43 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.38, as restoring ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for reusable and recyclable vehicles. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of making vehicles reusable and recyclable.

column2: (agricultural ecosystems) Member States shall put in place measures which shall aim to achieve an increasing trend at national level of at least two out of the three following indicators in agricultural ecosystems, as further specified in Annex IV, measured in the period from the date of entry into force of this Regulation until 31 December 2030, and every six years thereafter, until the satisfactory levels, identified in accordance with Article 14(5), are reached
column5: The implementation of TA6.44 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.49, as improving agricultural ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for recycled plastic from end-of-life vehicles. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of using recycled plastic from end-of-life vehicles.

column2: (agricultural ecosystems) Member States shall put in place restoration measures which shall aim to ensure that the common farmland bird index at national level based on the species specified in Annex V reaches the following levels: (a) 110 by 2030, 120 by 2040 and 130 by 2050, for Member States listed in Annex V with historically more depleted populations of farmland birds
column5: The implementation of TA6.45 is likely to have a negative impact on TA3.50, as restoring agricultural ecosystems can lead to increased biodiversity, which may reduce the need for reuse and recovery targets. This could make it more challenging to achieve the target of achieving reuse and recovery targets.
